**HEADLINE:** Renowned German Journalist Ralf Schuler Reflects on Formative Years at University of Virginia

**CHARLOTTESVILLE, VA** - In an exclusive interview, acclaimed German journalist Ralf Schuler opened up about his time at the University of Virginia, where he honed his craft and laid the foundation for a distinguished career in international reporting. Schuler, known for his in-depth coverage of global affairs and his fearless pursuit of truth, credits his experience at UVA with shaping his journalistic approach. "My time at the University of Virginia was instrumental in developing my critical thinking and storytelling skills," Schuler said, sitting down with our reporter in his Berlin office. "The university's strong emphasis on liberal arts and humanities provided a solid foundation for my future work as a journalist." During his time at UVA, Schuler was an active member of the university's student-run newspaper, The Cavalier Daily. He served as a reporter and later as editor-in-chief, covering a range of topics from local politics to international news. "Ralf was an exceptional journalist even back then," recalled his former colleague and friend, Emily Wilson, now a professor of journalism at UVA. "He had a keen sense of curiosity and a passion for telling stories that mattered." According to university records, Schuler graduated from UVA in 1995 with a degree in Media Studies. During his four years on campus, he was an engaged member of the university community, participating in various extracurricular activities and volunteering at the local NPR affiliate, WVTF. Schuler's experience at UVA also had a profound impact on his personal life. "It was during my time at UVA that I met my future wife, Anna," he shared, smiling. "We were both part of the same study abroad program in Paris, and the rest, as they say, is history." Since graduating from UVA, Schuler has gone on to become one of Germany's most respected and award-winning journalists. He has reported from conflict zones around the world, including Afghanistan, Iraq, and Ukraine, and has received numerous accolades for his work, including the prestigious German Journalism Award. When asked about the current state of journalism, Schuler emphasized the importance of a strong educational foundation. "In today's fast-paced and often chaotic media landscape, it's more crucial than ever that young journalists receive a solid education in the principles of reporting and storytelling," he said.
